subject: EnCiv - Home
description: EnCiv is forging the first-of-its-kind, cross-partisan discourse platform that enables Americans across the political spectrum to collaborate at scale to identify and address our toughest problems and drive tangible outcomes.

blocks.subject: Politics is dividing us - EnCiv is uniting us

blocks.description:
We’re trapped in a polarized echo chamber built to enrage citizens, control politicians, and drive We the People out of the political process.

EnCiv is forging the first-of-its-kind, cross-partisan discourse platform that enables Americans across the political spectrum to collaborate at scale to identify and address our toughest problems and drive tangible outcomes.

blocks.subject: National Deliberations
blocks.description:
We are hosting large scale national deliberations to identify the issues that unite us as a country and the solutions that have broad support across the political spectrum. Join us to be part of this historic effort to unite our country through productive discourse.

This is not a survey, this is a new kind of tool that is designed to help us discuss our ideas and productively converge on what unites us.

After expressing your views, you will get to see others, and you will get to say why some are more or less important to discuss further. And you will get to see what others say as well. Then after each round we will invite you back to be part of the next one, considering the most unifying ideas from the previous round, until we converge on the conclusions that unite us.

This is a new tool, early in its development and we invite you to provide feedback along the way so we can keep making it better.

blocks.subject: When we speak as One
blocks.description:
We’re fed up with (and frankly scared of) the current political system

Sick of partisan gridlock that stops real policy and productive discussion

Done with the media that only presents the most viral candidate moments and polarized takes

There is currently no cross-partisan discourse to address the biggest problems facing our country. And we can’t vote those solutions into power; once we get to the polls, it’s hard to know what policies and positions each candidate stands for.

**[65% of our country believes the current system is on the wrong track.](https://www.realclearpolling.com/polls/state-of-the-union/direction-of-country) Together, we can fix it.**

To overcome the forces polarizing us, we must have national discussions that organize, rather than suppress, differing voices and delve into the value of these perspectives to find the awesome solutions that unite us.

Join EnCiv to become part of a community of diverse, dedicated volunteers helping to foster this deliberation until politicians listen when we speak as one.

blocks.subject: No Partisanship. No Sponsorship. Just Productive Dialogue.
subPoints: We’ re nonpartisan – we never endorse a particular party, policy, or candidate.
We’re cross-partisan – we actively seek out and give voice to multiple perspectives.
We’re community-led and community-built – we’re not supported by any corporation.

blocks.subject: Built by the People, for the People
blocks.description:
If you believe that there's a better way to make the best national decisions and it starts with productive national dialogue...

**We're building it! Together.**

faqs.question: How do you deal with trolls?
faqs.answer:
In person dialog and deliberation has learned many techniques for dealing with negative actors. One of them is to take large groups of people and break them up into small groups around a table.  Motivations and rewards become different in small groups.

Another technique that they use is that in these small groups, people express their views, what they agree and disagree with, and then each small group decides on the top comments from the group. So if there were negative or destructive comments from a troll, they would be filtered out by the group - so no one else would have to listen to them.

Online, we use similar techniques. People's comments are grouped, a group reviews the comments, gives feedback, and then ranks them.  The highest ranked comments from each group feed forward to the next round of discussion.

faqs.question: How do you deal with disinformation?
faqs.answer: The weakness of disinformation is that it is crafted to appeal to a particular group of people. To people outside that group, it’s more apparent that the information is not true. Because we break discussions into small groups of random people, each group will likely include people who are and are not targets of similar disinformation tactics. Therefore, the varied perspectives and experiences within the group will allow participants to identify and filter out the disinformation and focus on the facts.

faqs.question: How do you moderate content?
faqs.answer: We do not moderate content. It is a community responsibility which one might call crowd moderation. In any discussion, a person will see ten people’s ‘content’ as responses to discussion questions. Users will be asked to rank which of the ten responses are most important for the community to consider. Through processes like this, the people participating will democratically decide on what content should be filtered out. This approach helps to avoid issues with biased moderators.

faqs.question: How can you achieve productive discussions across millions of people?
faqs.answer:
It’s about how we structure the conversation.  We don’t just put a million people into a chat room and ask them to talk. Our approach combines a proven technique from in-person dialogue and deliberation, breaking participants into small discussion groups, with online workflow technology that allows participants to continually distill the outputs of these small group discussions by taking the highest-ranked content from each group and distributing it to people again in a new round, like a tournament.            

So, when we have a million people (and we look forward to that), each person will look at what ten others said and pick the most important one or two for the community to consider. Then, in the next round, they will see ten of the highest-ranked items from the previous round. And so on.  After six rounds, a million ideas will have been democratically considered, discussed, and prioritized into a top few.  The discussion structure keeps it productive.

faqs.question: Where did the name EnCiv come from?
faqs.answer: EnCiv was originally taken from the combination of “engaged” and “civility.”

subject: Our Mission
description:
## Our Mission EnCiv exists to transform the way Americans practice democracy. We challenge sensationalism and polarization in our civic and political discourse by offering online tools to power widespread, cross-partisan discourse and a channel for better communication between candidates and voters to support better decision-making at the ballot box. ### Why Discourse Works EnCiv draws on decades of research into the principles of human interaction, civic discourse, dialogue and deliberation, and constructive decision-making. This research teaches us that well designed discussion processes that facilitate everyone speaking and listening yield the best results. While it’s easy to assume that online connection is inferior to live interactions in fostering respect and constructive collaboration, we believe the opposite. When supported by systems designed with neutrality in mind, online discourse has the potential to establish a higher bar for universally respectful, broadly inclusive conversation — ultimately driving positive results. ### The EnCiv Team

David Fridley CEO, Chairperson of the Board, CTO. Social Entrepreneur, Founder of Synaccord, LLC, product manager, full stack developer, and 30+ years experience in voice and video over the internet. He received his MBA from Suffolk University, holds a BA in Computer Science from UC San Diego, and has over 12 years of experience in software and hardware engineering.


Adolf G. Gundersen, Co-Founder, Board Member, VP & Research Director at Interactivity Foundation. Thirty years experience as theorist and practitioner of democratic discussion. Widely published in the field of democratic discourse, most recently as co-author of Let's Talk Politics: Restoring Civility through Exploratory Discussion. Ph.D. in political science.


Sorin Matei, Board Member of EnCiv, Communications Professor, Purdue University. Matei studies the relationship between information technology and social structures. His teaching portfolio includes social media analytics, online interaction and facilitation, and global social media research. Ph.D. in communication.

subject: Our Tools
description:
##We’re building tech tools for a better democracy.

As cultural polarization and sensationalism continue to threaten civic discourse, we see a technological opportunity. Our tools provide an alternative to current discourse and political education processes, fostering productive discourse in a way that will ultimately drive better decision making.

We currently have two tools available: Undebates and Civil Pursuit. Join our mailing list to stay informed of our new product releases.

###Undebates

More Informed Decisions at the Ballot Box

---

**Problem**: Whether it's the school board or the student council, it's hard for voters to really understand the candidates’ positions on the questions that matter most. Written information is scattered across the internet and any media coverage is short and sensationalized. And for candidates, it can be almost impossible to get honest media coverage if they’re not running for president.

**Solution:** Undebates is a tool that automatically produces video debates by automatically interviewing candidates through their web browser. Instead of sitting through debates or combing through news articles, hear the candidates’ position on the policies you care about most, straight from them and make your own informed voting decisions.

Democratically-run organizations and political candidates at any level can create their own Undebates with a few simple steps.

<ActionButton style="lineHeight:6rem;" action="https://cc.enciv.org/undebates">See Undebates in Action</ActionButton>

###Civil Pursuit

Large Scale Deliberative Discussion

---

**Problem:** How can thousands of people across the city, state, and country discuss tough political issues productively - meaning discussions resulting in solutions they all support - rather than the polarization and gridlock we see from politics today?

**Solution:** We are building tools for productive democratic deliberation online, based on practices that have been proven through in-person dialog and deliberation. With Civil Pursuit, you can browse a series of burning questions in our current political ecosystem, and participate in structured discussions with people across the country that are designed to organize, rather than suppress, differing opinions and delve into what's valuable in each that lead to unifying solutions with national support.

<ActionButton style="margin-top:2rem">Coming Soon</ActionButton>

subject: A New Vision of Democracy
description: The article titled: "A New Vision of Democracy"

article.title: A New Vision of Democracy
article.content:
EnCiv’s David Fridley has been working in the field of online democracy for years.  He shared an early statement of his vision for an “Online Deliberative Constitutional Representative Democracy” on Quora.

You can read the original post here.  While it focuses on national deliberation, keep in mind that the technology at its core could also be used at smaller scales.  Indeed, because small tournaments can be run in less time than larger ones, the smaller the scale, the faster the tool would produce meaningful results.  Deliberation “at scale” isn’t different from deliberation with your immediate neighbors or club members; it just takes longer.  But not a great deal longer.  As Fridley points out in his post, eight or nine rounds of deliberation would be enough to connect the whole US population in a single deliberative event.  Collective deliberation on such a scale would be unprecedented.  Would it take any longer than an election, which is the collective expression of “the people’s will”?  Let’s try it and find out.

subject: What one issue should 'We the People' unite and solve first to move our country in the right direction?
description:
United, we can solve our biggest problems! But to succeed, we need to find a way to agree and focus on one at a time. The one issue that everyone from across the political spectrum would agree has a positive impact. Then we can solve it and move on to the next one.

Take a moment and think about it, but don't over think your answer at this point. You will probably have a new perspective after this. This is just the beginning.

stepIntro.subject: Some details
stepIntro.description: We ask these questions about participants to help us achieve broad ideological participation.  In order to find the best possible solutions, and the ones that unite the nation, all ideas need to be represented.

shareInfo.title: Personally Identifiable Information is not shown, but may we share this information with your posts?

stepIntro.subject: Answer
stepIntro.description:
Please answer the question below, and provide a short headline for it. Then in the second section, please explain why it's important for everyone to consider this answer.

In steps that follow,you will get to see others' answers and explanations, but to maximize the opportunity for independent new ideas, we ask everyone to answer the question first before seeing others' answers.

question.subject: What one issue should 'We the People' unite and solve first to move our country in the right direction?
question.description: United, we can solve our biggest problems! But to succeed, we need to find a way to agree and focus on one at a time. The one issue that everyone from across the political spectrum would agree has a positive impact?

steps.whyQuestion: Why should everyone unite around solving this issue first?

stepIntro.subject: Group Responses
stepIntro.description: Of these responses, please group similar responses, and choose one to be the lead. If none are similar, please continue to the next section.

stepIntro.subject: Rank Responses
stepIntro.description: Please rate the following responses as Most, Neutral, or Least important to discuss further. All need to be rated, and in future steps you will be asked to explain why you rated them that way. See below for how many must be rated Most and Least important.

stepIntro.subject: Why it's Most Important
stepIntro.description: Of the issues you thought were Most important to discuss further, please give a brief explanation of why it's valuable for everyone to consider it.

stepIntro.subject: Why it's Least Important
stepIntro.description: Of the issues you thought were least important to discuss further, please give a brief explanation of why it's least valuable for everyone to consider further.

stepIntro.subject: Compare Reasons Why It's Most Important
stepIntro.description: Responses will be presented side by side. Select the one you think is the strongest explanation. If there is only one left, select Yes if its strong enough for everyone to consider, or No if not. At the end you can choose Start Over if you want to reconsider your choices.

stepIntro.subject: Compare Reasons Why It's Least Important
stepIntro.description: Responses will be presented side by side. Select the one you think is the strongest explanation. If there is only one left, select Yes if its strong enough for everyone to consider, or No if not. At the end you can choose Start Over if you want to reconsider your choices.

stepIntro.subject: Review
stepIntro.description: These are the issues you sorted earlier, with reasons added by the discussion. Please consider the reasons and sort the list again.

stepIntro.subject: Feedback
stepIntro.description: Now that you've completed this round, please tells us what you think so far. This is a work in progress and your feedback matters.

elements.text: How has your experience been so far?
How comfortable would you feel inviting close friends or family to participate in this discussion too?
How interested are you in getting to the next round of this discussion?
What can we do to make this tool better?

stepIntro.subject: Intermission
stepIntro.description: When more people have gotten to this point we will invite you back to continue the deliberation.

stepIntro.subject: Feedback
stepIntro.description: Thanks for completing the discussion. Please provide some final feedback to help us improve this tool.

elements.text: What's your overall rating for this kind of discussion tool?
How comfortable would you feel inviting close friends or family to participate in this discussion too?
Would you like to participate in more discussions like this
What can we do to make this tool better, get more people involved, or is there anything else we should know?

subject: What structural change would most effectively restore public trust in the integrity and function of our key national institutions (media, government, courts)?
description: Most agree that trust in our institutions is declining. Some will think about ethics and transparency, others will think about media bias and bureaucracy. And, if we can work together and find the things that unites us, we can make a difference.

subject: Beyond the current debt, what is the most important national long-term investment (20+ years) we should agree on and commit to today?
description: Identifying a Highest-Supported Answer on a 20-year investment is the only way to escape the cycle of partisan flip-flopping, providing the stability required to make massive, lasting improvements to the nation. A Unifying Solution provides the stable, long-term roadmap needed to ensure America’s future prosperity and competitiveness.

subject: What questions of national interest will be most valuable to consider and find unifying answers to?
description: Are the most important issues even being discussed today? Are there topics that have been too tough to talk about? The questions we choose to consider together shape the future we create.

stepIntro.subject: Some details
stepIntro.description: We ask these questions about participants to help us achieve broad ideological participation.  In order to find the best possible solutions, and the ones that unite the nation, all ideas need to be represented.

shareInfo.title: Personally Identifiable Information is not shown, but may we share this information with your posts?

stepIntro.subject: Answer
stepIntro.description:
Please answer the question below, and provide a short headline for it. Then in the second section, please explain why it's important for everyone to consider this answer.

In steps that follow,you will get to see others' answers and explanations, but to maximize the opportunity for independent new ideas, we ask everyone to answer the question first before seeing others' answers.

steps.whyQuestion: Why is this question important for everyone to consider?

stepIntro.subject: Group Responses
stepIntro.description: Of these responses, please group similar responses, and choose one to be the lead. If none are similar, please continue to the next section.

stepIntro.subject: Rank Responses
stepIntro.description: Please rate the following responses as Most, Neutral, or Least important to discuss further. All need to be rated, and in future steps you will be asked to explain why you rated them that way. See below for how many must be rated Most and Least important.

stepIntro.subject: Why it's Most Important
stepIntro.description: Of the issues you thought were Most important to discuss further, please give a brief explanation of why it's valuable for everyone to consider it.

stepIntro.subject: Why it's Least Important
stepIntro.description: Of the issues you thought were least important to discuss further, please give a brief explanation of why it's less valuable for everyone to consider further.

stepIntro.subject: Compare Reasons Why It's Most Important
stepIntro.description: Responses will be presented side by side. Select the one you think is the strongest explanation. If there is only one left, select Useful if its strong enough for everyone to consider, or Not Useful if not. At the end you can choose Start Over if you want to reconsider your choices.

stepIntro.subject: Compare Reasons Why It's Least Important
stepIntro.description: Responses will be presented side by side. Select the one you think is the strongest explanation. If there is only one left, select Useful if its strong enough for everyone to consider, or Not Useful if not. At the end you can choose Start Over if you want to reconsider your choices.

stepIntro.subject: Review
stepIntro.description: These are the issues you sorted earlier, with reasons added by the discussion. Please consider the reasons and sort the list again.

stepIntro.subject: Feedback
stepIntro.description: Now that you've completed this round, please tells us what you think so far. This is a work in progress and your feedback matters.

elements.text: How has your experience been so far?
How comfortable would you feel inviting close friends or family to participate in this discussion too?
How interested are you in getting to the next round of this discussion?
What can we do to make this tool better?

stepIntro.subject: Intermission
stepIntro.description: When more people have gotten to this point we will invite you back to continue the deliberation.

stepIntro.subject: Feedback
stepIntro.description: Thanks for completing the discussion. Please provide some final feedback to help us improve this tool.

Would you like to participate in more discussions like this
What can we do to make this tool better, get more people involved, or is there anything else we should know?

subject: What Do We Want Government To Do?
description:
## Define the Mission: What Should Government Actually Do?

Worried about the political polarization? So are we.

Public discourse is being defined by for-profit algorithms, and most voices aren't heard. This new, non-partisan deliberation offers a chance to step away from the noise and **find what unites us.**

Join people from across the entire political spectrum—conservatives, liberals, and everyone in between—for one essential purpose: to collaboratively draft a single, shared, **concise** Vision Statement on the fundamental role and purpose of our government.

This is not a debate about policy or personalities. This is a foundational conversation about **principles** that will become the basis of further deliberations.

Move beyond gridlock. Write the **Mission Statement** for the next generation—your perspective isn't just heard; it's written into the core text.

Invest some time. Help define the mission that **unites** us.

subject: What direction for our country would unite us in pursuit of it?
description:
### **Your unique perspective is the starting point.**

Most platforms want you to react. We want you to **lead.** We are often told our country is "lost," but the truth is we simply **aren’t looking at the same map.** We need your unfiltered, honest vision—no matter how out-of-the-box or "awkward" it may feel. Sometimes the ideas that seem unconventional at first are the ones that spark a breakthrough for everyone else.

#### **The Process: The "First 500" Tournament**
We are looking for 500 **distinct voices** to launch this deliberation. Once we hit that threshold, the process begins:

1.  **The Initial View:** You will see and rank a selection of 8 ideas (including yours).
2.  **The Deep Dive:** You will then deliberate on the 8 highest-ranked ideas from that round.
3.  **The Consensus:** You will focus on the top-tier ideas to see which direction has the strongest potential to unite us all.
4.  **The Reveal:** We will share the final results with all participants and the public, creating a clear signal of where we can go together.

**Beyond the Pilot:** Everyone in the "First 500" will be invited to participate in—and help shape—future, larger-scale deliberations as we grow.

#### **What to share now:**
* **The Direction:** In your view, what is the path our country should take?
* **The Case for Unity:** Why do you believe this is a direction that—once understood—the rest of the country could (or should) unite behind?

#### **The Big Picture: Scaling a New Democracy**
Today, you are a pioneer of a new civic infrastructure. We are proving the model with 500 people, but **the goal is to scale to thousands, then millions, and eventually the whole country.** Imagine a future where "the will of the people" isn't a guess by a pollster, but a clear, deliberated direction we have defined together.

> **Note:** Responses are not shown until we hit 500 participants. This ensures each vision is an **original perspective**, uninfluenced by what anyone else has written.

Answering is optional, and this info is not shown along side your posts unless you give permission below.

shareInfo.title: Show this information along with your posts? (Your personally identifiable information will not be shown, but this info may help people understand the perspective)

stepIntro.subject: Group Responses
stepIntro.description: Of these responses, please group similar responses, and choose one to be the lead. If none are similar, please continue to the next section.

stepIntro.subject: Rank Responses
stepIntro.description: Please rate the following responses as Most, Neutral, or Least likely that people would unite behind. All need to be rated, and in future steps you will be asked to explain why you rated them most or least. If you see one that is inappropriate or offensive, rate it as neutral. If others agree, it won't go any further.  See below for how many must be rated Most and Least important.

stepIntro.subject: Why it's Most Likely
stepIntro.description: Of the issues you thought were Most likely to unite people, please give a brief explanation of why.

stepIntro.subject: Why it's Least Likely
stepIntro.description: Of the issues you thought were least likely to unite people, please give a brief explanation of why.

stepIntro.subject: Compare Reasons Why It's Most Likely
stepIntro.description: Responses will be presented side by side. Select the one you think is the strongest explanation. If there is only one left, select Yes if its strong enough for everyone to consider, or No if not. At the end you can choose Start Over if you want to reconsider your choices.

stepIntro.subject: Compare Reasons Why It's Least Likely
stepIntro.description: Responses will be presented side by side. Select the one you think is the strongest explanation. If there is only one left, select Yes if its strong enough for everyone to consider, or No if not. At the end you can choose Start Over if you want to reconsider your choices.

stepIntro.subject: Review
stepIntro.description: These are the issues you sorted earlier, with reasons why they are most or least likely to unite people added by the discussion. Please consider the reasons and sort the list again.
